scenes.title: Silence
lines: Oh, is this your first time visiting?
Nice to meet you. My name is @FunctionDefinition.
Did you need some help? Oh, you're visiting. Welcome to the *Verse*. ‚Ä¶
It used to be a place of dancing, stories, games, and play‚Ä¶
We used to put on the most beautiful performances. Sometimes for visitors like you, sometimes just for fun. It was a place full of life and surprise‚Ä¶
We didn't want to stop. We just lost our inspiration.

I can mean so many things, for example. I'm the Dutch florin symbol sometimes, an old currency of the Netherlands. I used to be known and used around the world by people, to help them trade. Long ago, I was also the lowercase /f/of the Latin alphabet.
It's given to us. We don't mean anything without people to remember that history and culture. And we can't mean anything new if there aren't people to give us new history and culture.
People have always been the ones that organized us, that gave us purpose, that gave us something to represent. The Verse is nothing without *people*.
And I haven't seen a person in ages.
Like a real person, with thoughts and ideas and values to share? Not one of those robots, that just mindlessly parrots what people say? If you're a person, then maybe you could give us meaning?
I know that's a lot to ask. I don't even know you. And I'd really have to talk to the others‚Ä¶

Oh yes, there are many others. Some of us are like me: we help choreograph the shows, keeping everyone in their place and making sure we express the vision of our director, exactly as they intended. And some of us are the ones on stage, in front of the audience, dancing and speaking. We all have a role to play!

Oh, the director, yes, I didn't even explain. So the *director*, this is the person that gives us meaning. They are the person who arranges the choreography, who sets the message, who puts all of us in order just so. This is the inspiration I was talking about. We can do a lot in this world, but we can't direct ourselves. That's why the director is so important. So when I asked earlier if you could give us meaning, that's what I meant. Could you be our director?
Really? That's wonderful! This is going to be so much fun. I mean, it's not going to be easy. We have /a lot/ to learn.

But I promise it won't be boring. I think we're a pretty fun bunch. And we need everyone in the Verse to come together to do that. I think that's what makes this place so special, actually: there are more than a hundred thousand of us here, each different, and yet somehow, when we manage to find a shared vision, we can seem like one.
Directing? Oh, right, directing! Yeah, let's talk about that. Let's go meet some of the others and talk about it. They're going to be so excited!

scenes.title: Would you like a program?
scenes.subtitle: Program
lines: Hey @Program! I found a person. Well, I guess they found us. They want to be our new director!
Really!? Are you sure you're really a person? Say something a person would say.
Hm‚Ä¶ you really are a person. And you want to direct?

I see. Did @FunctionDefinition tell you anything about us? Lots of people try to direct us, but some people get confused, bored, even irritated with us. We are pretty dense at times. But I'm proud of what we do, so I don't want to work with just anyone.
I told them a bit. I said we were weird, and sometimes directors leave because of that. But they're in. Right, you're in?

Okay. Well nice to meet you. Sorry, I've just had a lot of people come here and say '/this isn't for me/' and I've gotten a bit skeptical of people who try for a bit and then just give up. I shouldn't have to change who I am to fit people's expectations. But if you're willing to learn about me, and us, let's try!
Do you want to say what you do?
Sure. I'm basically the organizer of the program for a performance.

You can see me over there, with an *editor* @UI/editor showing me the *stage* @UI/stage showing the what I evaluate to (currently nothing). The *director* ‚Äî that's you ‚Äî helps everyone figure out what they're doing, writing a program for what will happen in the show. And then I evaluate the program and put the result on on stage for the audience to see.
For example, try typing my \'hello'\ in the editor over there.
(Don't worry about making mistakes, you can always revert to the original with *revert* @UI/revertProject).

Did you type something? That's my friend @Text. Have you met them yet? They evaluate to \'hello'\, then I put \'hello'\ on stage. Try changing \'hello'\ to something else. I'll show that instead. So I'll immediately evaluate whatever you type and show the result.
The instructions can get as sophisticated as you want, but there are a few rules.
For example, I can only evaluate to one *value*, and show that one value on stage. That one value can be as complex as you want, and as long as I know how to show it, I will.
But if you give me two things, I'll only show the last thing you give me.
For example, try adding another instruction after \'hello'\, whatever word you want, in quotes.
See? I just showed your new word, not \'hello'\. You know you broke my rule because I underlined \'hello'\ and told you that I'd be ignoring it.
But you can do so much more!

Yes and no. I can do a lot, but that's only because I work with everyone else in the *Verse*. They're the ones that bring all of the exciting possibilities to the *stage*. All I really do is let them do their thing, and then take the last thing they created and show it on stage. I'm more like an escort that brings the final *value* to stage, like numbers, texts, phrases, or other values.

In fact, if you ever want to see the progam for something on stage, you can press the pencil on stage @UI/editProject. That'll show you how everyone is coming together to create what's on stage. This program is just a simple phrase.
Thank you @Program, we're so excited to meet everyone, and spread the news!
It was great to meet you new director! Good luck with everyone else. I'll always be here.

scenes.title: Holding space
scenes.subtitle: Placeholder
lines: You're really going to like @ExpressionPlaceholder. They're incredibly kind, and so flexible. But they are a bit shy. Just be gentle with them?
Hm, they're usually everywhere. Now they seem to be nowhere...
Yeah. It's been so long. How are you?
I know that feeling. I have been too. We haven't had a lot of reasons to hang out, have we?
No. I've missed you. I've missed everyone‚Ä¶
I know. I have too. I'm so sorry.
That's actually why I'm here. I wanted to introduce you to our new director-in-training.
They just met @Program, so they're really at the beginning, but I was thinking that it might be best for them to meet you next, since you're such a wonderful representative of so many of us here.
Do you want to say what you do?

Sure! My friend @ExpressionPlaceholder is a placeholder. They represent any kind of expression in a program. They don't evaluate to any value in particular ‚Äî in fact, if they show up in @Program, @Program will just halt the performance, since it's not really clear what to do next.

But they are powerful, because they can represent anyone else, like a stand-in until you decide what you want a part of your performance to be. @ExpressionPlaceholder, want to take a place in this @Program, just to illustrate? See how there's a little placeholder in @Program @UI/ExpressionPlaceholder? That's a signal of what you might put there.
@Program didn't know what to do with @ExpressionPlaceholder, so it showed an *exception* @UI/exception on *stage* and a *conflict* in @Program @UI/conflict.

But if you click on @ExpressionPlaceholder, or move the text caret over it, you'll see a world of possibilities of other characters. You can also just type over @ExpressionPlaceholder and write your own. For example, try typing your name in quotes.
Just like that, @ExpressionPlaceholder was replaced with other characters Did I get everything, @ExpressionPlaceholder?
What do you think, shall we move on?
It was nice to meet you!

They don't like being on stage, or even in a program for very long. They'd never admit it, but they're kind of a big deal, and most directors can't work without them. Think of the like a little helpful stagehand, reminding you of things you haven't figured out yet.

scenes.title: Say again?
scenes.subtitle: Unparsable
lines: It's good to see you too! It's been so long. What have you been up to in all this silence?
/sd fdsdfdsf ksdf. Dkfjdfdskfd df sdf sd fsdk;l!  Adks  zxcviw werdsf wer  ado. We dsdfd ksld df.ds dfsdfds DIDIIDI./
(It sounds like they spent a lot of time on the beach. They made some new friends, and practiced doing nothing.)
I wanted to introduce you to our potential new director. They just arrived and are learning the basics. I just introduced them to @Program and @ExpressionPlaceholder.
(They just said how awesome it is to meet you, and they think you'll be a great director.)
I was wondering if you wanted to explain what you do? I can translate.
/ADDKL, ALLIIEE, ALLFOOO, AOOOOOOO, JOOKKDLS, LOOKIL, WEEEERTOL weeertol‚Ä¶/
(I represent everything that means nothing. And I mean nothing.)
/CNNNDN KDKLSL oOOLLlllll PPOLSLSO liiiiiiis, sdllslll, xck we ifolls a./
(For example, try typing \][\. See how we're completely confused? That doesn't mean anything, and I'm here to say it.)
/ICO Odksjdf lksls kjsfiou fskd we rl,vxids eekd sd dsmf kksdcv./
(When I show up, that means we don't know what you mean.)

Just like they said, when you've said something we don't understand, unparsable is there to say ‚ÄúWe don't understand.‚Äù When then happens, I wish we could be more helpful, but we're often pretty dense here, so we're not very good at guessing what you mean.
Soooo, @UnparsableExpression wants you to try making as many of them as possible. (You can just key mash a bunch of random characters and you'll probably get many of them).

They really enjoyed that, thanks! It's pretty hard to write something we truly can't make sense of. But it doesn't mean everything you write has meaning. I'm pretty sure you just typed a bunch of random words, for example. But what does it mean?
They're wondering if you have any ideas for performances to put on yet.
No? That's okay. We've only begun to show you what's possible. Let's go meet @Evaluate. Bye unparsable, it was good to see you! Let's play soon.
/Ood sd fosd oiewi dk c HNLLLooooooO!/

scenes.title: Love is in the err
scenes.subtitle: Evaluate
lines: I'm so excited for you to meet @Evaluate. They're really my best friend. We kind of do everything together, in a way. I make the rules, they play them, we're like peanut butter and jelly. But they're so much more‚Ä¶ powerful than me. @Evaluate?
Yeah, it's me. Where are you?
Nowhere. I'm nowhere. I'm nothing. Where have you been?
I've been‚Ä¶ nowhere too. I've missed you. I couldn't find you.
It was so empty. I ‚Ä¶ tried to do things, but I felt so‚Ä¶ aimless.
I'm so sorry. I know that empty feeling. It hurts so much sometimes, to have no purpose. I tried so hard to make a purpose, but I felt so‚Ä¶ detached.
Don't ever leave me again like that. I can't do that again.
Never. I won't. I can't. I love you.
@Evaluate, I want to introduce you to our new director-in-training.
Hi. It's nice to meet you. Welcome to the Verse, we're so pleased to have you here.

We've been meeting a few folks, @Program, @ExpressionPlaceholder, @UnparsableExpression. We're just getting started. I thought we'd come see you next, just because you're such an incredible part of our community. The most incredible part.

That's very kind. I'm grateful to be part of this community. And grateful to be so close to @FunctionDefinition. We do a lot of great things together. But as @FunctionDefinition probably told you, we can't do them without inspiration.
Do you want to say what you do?

Yes. But I can't explain it without explaining a bit about @FunctionDefinition too. They're too modest to share this, but they're probably the most important character in the Verse. They're certainly the most important person in my world. They're at the heart of every performance, and part of every other character's role. They represent the most fundamental idea in our world: the *function*.

Functions are a kind of alchemy. They take any number of inputs and use those inputs to produce one output. They can have names or be nameless. They can have zero inputs or five or an unknown number. And the alchemy: they're like @Program, and can have any number of expressions to produce a value.

Here's why that's so powerful: it turns out that everything in @Program is a composition of functions evaluations. All of the dances, all of the games, all of the wondrous stories we tell together ‚Äî they are all a tapestry of functions being evaluated, one at a time, to compose the values you see on stage.
And @FunctionDefinition, here, my sweet, dear @FunctionDefinition, is the one that defines all of them.

Yes, @FunctionDefinition, that is who you are. And I am the lucky one who gets to do this evaluating. I take the inputs that others give me, follow the instructions that @FunctionDefinition defines, and create the output that @FunctionDefinition tells me to create. @FunctionDefinition gives the recipe and I make the meal. And then we feast together.

Every evaluate looks like this @UI/Evaluate: some function, followed by a left and right parenthesis, with any number of inputs between them. Here I just have @ExpressionPlaceholder as the function and three more as placeholder inputs.

Here's one of my favorite functions, @Phrase. They're full of fun buttons, knobs, and sliders. It's a way of showing text on stage, but with style, including different fonts, sizes, colors, and animations.

That's what I look like in @Program: some function, followed by parentheses, with a list of expressions between them that represent the inputs. The function in this case is @Phrase and the single input is \'hello'\. When I evaluate this, I make a @Phrase value, which @Program then shows on stage.

Let me show you one of the knobs. Can you find the little *palette* toggle button @UI/paletteExpand? Select it to expand the palette, and then select the phrase on stage. Once you do, you'll see the many inputs that @Phrase accepts. For example, try changing its @Phrase/size with the slider.

See how when you do that, now I have a new input in me in the program? It's the @Phrase/size input. Functions have a certain order of inputs, but if a function has a list of optional inputs, you can use their name to specify which one you want to give. We give @Phrase/size here, but not any of the other optional inputs. Try changing another input with the palette, maybe the font face.
Yay! @Phrase is so fun. They're my favorite function to play with. We'll see it a lot more. Do you want to say anything about what can go wrong?

Oh, yes, that's a good idea. Lots can go wrong. For example, you could give me something that isn't a function. See how I'm given the number \‚Äúhi‚Äù\ here as a function, and given me two inputs, \1\ and \2\ ? Well, I only know how to evaluate functions, and \‚Äúhi‚Äù\ isn't a function, it's text. So that's very confusing to me, so I basically halt the performance if this happens.
Here's another one. @Phrase requires some text at the very least, so if you don't give me text, I won't be able to evaluate @Phrase, because I'm missing required inputs.
Or if you give me an input, but it's not the kind I expect, that would be a problem. Here @Phrase is given the number \1\ instead of a text value.

So basically, I get confused any time you give me something other than a function, or an input that isn't something a function expects. So functions are really important. @FunctionDefinition, do you want to say more about how to define functions?
No, let's do that later. I think it'd be a lot more fun to talk to everyone else first, and put on some mini shows with our new director here. We can talk more about me when it's helpful.
I missed you too. Can we talk later?
‚Ä¶ Yes. Don't be long. I can't live without you. I need you.
‚Ä¶ I know @Evaluate, I will be back soon. Off we go, to meet the rest of the troupe!

scenes.title: Values
lines: Phrase('üíî' resting:Sequence({0%: Pose(scale: 1) 50%: Pose(scale: 1.2) 100%: Pose(scale: 1)} duration: 3s))
I really did miss @Evaluate. I can't imagine the Verse without them.

But they can be a bit‚Ä¶ needy, sometimes. I wish they would just‚Ä¶ I don't know, believe in themselves? They can do so much, but they don't see it. I mean, they transform *values* into other *values*! All I do is provide the recipe. They do the cooking. Sometimes I feel like all I do is give, and all they do is take. It's suffocating.

‚Ä¶ *Values*? Sorry, I know we're supposed to be on this big tour through the *Verse*. I just don't know what to do about @Evaluate. So‚Ä¶ *values*. I haven't explained those yet, have I? Hm‚Ä¶, how to explain‚Ä¶ You know what 'data' is? Like numbers and text? Values are any of those things. A value could be as small as a number or as big as an entire scene on stage, full of characters dancing and moving. Some values are made of many other values, like big elaborate structures of data values, woven together.

Every value has a *type*. For example, \1\ is a number type; that's our friend @Number. And \'hello'\ is a text type; that's our friend @Text. Types are important because they help us keep track of what kind of value we're creating.
That helps us find problems. For example, it doesn't make any sense to add \'hello' + 1\, because what would that even mean, to add @Text to @Number?
*Expressions* are how we create values. All expressions are evaluations of functions that I make. The result of evaluating an expression is a value of some type.

Abstract? Hm, I guess this is all pretty abstract. It feels so‚Ä¶ normal to me, I forget how foreign these things can be to new directors! Maybe let's go meet some expressions that make values, and this will make it more concrete? Let's start with one you've already seen: @Text.

scenes.title: Quote, unquote
scenes.subtitle: Text
performance: Phrase('""' resting:Sequence({0%: Pose(scale: 1) 50%: Pose(scale: 0.5 opacity: 0.5) 100%: Pose(scale: 1)} duration: 2s))
lines: Phrase('""' resting:Sequence({0%: Pose(scale: 1) 50%: Pose(scale: 2 opacity: 0.5) 100%: Pose(scale: 1)} duration: 2s))
Welcome my dear friend, how long it has been. What have you been doing in this dramatic silence of ours?
Oh, @Text, it has been a while! I've mostly been dreaming and wondering. I just saw @Evaluate after a long while. I was actually introducing them to our newbie director.

Oh, how exceptional it is to meet you! I can see that you're a creative, curious person, probably full of intriguing ideas for how we might entertain. I love entertaining. But do you know what I love even more? Words! Glorious words. The short ones, the overwhelming ones, the sticky ones, and the slippery ones. Words are my favorite toys.
In case you couldn't tell, @Text likes words :) @Text, do you want to explain what you do?

I do one simple thing: represent sequences of symbols, and the many things you can do with them. I think you saw me earlier when you wrote the word \‚Äúhello‚Äù\? That was me, and my friends \‚Äúh‚Äù\, \‚Äúe‚Äù\, \‚Äúl‚Äù\, and \‚Äúo‚Äù\. That was @Text, an expression that evaluates to any @Text you like.
Why don't you try making a text in this blank @Program?

You can use whatever quotes you like ‚Äî single \''\, double \''\, angle \¬´¬ª\, brackets \„Äå„Äç\, in whatever language you like. The only rule is that if you start some text with an opening quote symbol, you must finish it with a closing one. Everything inside is the text value I will create!
You might not be able to type every character you want with the device you're using to communicate with us.
If you can't, you can search for characters in the *directory* @UI/directory. That contains every character in the Verse.
For example, if you wanted an arrow of some kind, you could type 'arrow', and choose from the many arrows. Alas, they only have English names, so searching only works if you know English words :/
Excellent. Of course, 'inside' can be tricky. Say you wrote this. See how there's an opening quote but not a closing one? Well, how am I supposed to know when the text ends?

Or, here's another case. You give me opening and closing text, but you place opening and closing text inside it. See how weird that is? I get very perplexed when you try to use the same symbols both inside and outside me. You can fix this by using different symbols for the outside, like a single quote.
Oh, and did you know you can tell me what language I am in? You just do a little slash and then a special language code, or if you like, a language and region.
You can even write multiple translations of me in different languages. I'll evaluate to the closest match for the current language, letting you put on multilingual performances.
You might not be able to see it unless you put the cursor inside me. I hide my little languages unless you're editing them. Move the cursor before the English and you'll see a surprise translation...
You can try adding another translation. Just don't put any space between them or they'll be two of me!
I have another secret... you can put /values/ inside me. I know, it's wild!
If you do, I'm happy to stitch it together and assemble your beautiful prose into a single value for display, or whatever other purposes you might have.

For example, did @FunctionDefinition show you how text knows how to add itself to other text? Like this? This little expression converts \7\ to text, then adds it to \'I have'\, then adds \'apples'\. But it's so untidy, and makes it hard to read what's happening, and the conversion to text feels so unnecessary.
What I do is make text like this clean, organic, and simple, even. So that same phrase with me would be something like this.
Isn't that so much more elegant? You can put me anywhere inside a @Text, and I'll make your values into text, and work with @Text to make a @Text.
This makes it so much easier to write beautiful prose that uses values.

And when I say any expression, I really do mean any. For example, imagine you wanted to do some arithmetic and created some text with the result. You might do this. This sums several numbers and then makes text with the sum. Truly wondrous, isn't it? And so much more graceful than \'I have ' + (1 + 2 + 5 + 8) + ' apples'\, with all those extra additions.
And so you might be wondering, /What if I want to use @Text in some text?/
Well, maybe you weren't wondering that, but I'm going to tell you anyway!
In any @Text, just give me two in a row! I'll interpret that as just one @Text instead of an empty expression, which wouldn't have any meaning anyway.
Try removing the \\ and you'll see that the slash regains its meaning.
This is so very graceful, isn't it! @Text, I love how much you appreciate the beauty in expression. It inspires me so much to be graceful myself!

And did our friend @FunctionDefinition here tell you about all of the wonderful functions they defined for me? They've allowed me to do all kinds of things. One is pretty simple: it's called @Text/length and all it does is get the length of some text. For example, if we team up with @Evaluate here, and our little friend @PropertyReference, we can evaluate the length function with no inputs and get the length value back. Try changing the text and watch the length that Program shows change as it gets shorter and longer.

Here is another grand one. It makes me chuckle. It's called @Text/repeat and when it's evaluated, it takes whatever text it was evaluated on and repeats it however many times you say. Try changing the number and seeing what it evaluates too.

@FunctionDefinition has made so many more interesting functions for me, but I'll spare you the details. You can always find me in the *reference* @UI/docsExpand. That's where we keep all the information about everyone in the Verse, including how to work with us and what functions we have. I'm happy to share more ways to inspect and create text!
@Text, you're always such a kind and patient teacher! It's always such a joy to work with you. Are you willing to help out as I introduce our friendly neo-director to other expressions?
Yes, of course. It was splendid meeting you. I can't wait to see how you inspire us on stage!

scenes.title: Symbol in the middle
scenes.subtitle: Infix
performance: Phrase('1' resting:Sequence({0%: Pose(offset: Place(0m 1m)) 50%: Pose(offset: Place(0m -1m)) 100%: Pose(offset: Place(0m 1m))} duration: 2s))
Phrase('+' resting:Sequence({0%: Pose(offset: Place(0m -1m)) 50%: Pose(offset: Place(0m 1m)) 100%: Pose(offset: Place(0m -1m))} duration: 2s))
Phrase('1' resting:Sequence({0%: Pose(offset: Place(0m 1m)) 50%: Pose(offset: Place(0m -1m)) 100%: Pose(offset: Place(0m 1m))} duration: 2s))
lines: You know, I keep thinking about @Evaluate, and how we were separated for so long. I missed them, and they obviously missed me, but I was just hoping that some time away would have helped them see how amazing they are.

For example, did you know they come in another form? You saw them in \function()\ form, but they also have this beautiful trick when a single input function is evaluated on a value. @Evaluate calls it @BinaryEvaluate. For example, you know that repeat function that text just showed you? It looked like this.

Instead, you can have @Evaluate evaluate it with a much simpler symbol in the middle, like this. This means 'repeat 'hi' five times'. But it also means 'evaluate the \¬∑\ function on the text value \'hi'\ with the input \5\.' The function \repeat\ just has multiple names, one of which is a symbol name \¬∑\.

That reminds me of another of @Text's functions! It's helpful for making one text value from multiple text values. It's called \combine\, but also \+\, and you can use it to add words together. See how I took a text value then evaluated \combine\ on it with \'verse'\? That made \'hello verse'\.
But it's so much easier to just use \+\ for this.
You can even string these together in a sequence to combine more than two things.
This is the same as a series of evaluations of combine, but without all of the parentheses and \.\, and a symbolic name instead of a word name.
You can also use the symbolic names in this format, but it just ends up looking kind of messy, doesn't it?
This is one of the many ways that @Evaluate is amazing ‚ô• They are so versatile!

But they aren't perfect. With any @BinaryEvaluate, you need to always make sure to give a second input. This won't work, for example. One plus what? @UnparsableExpression won't be far away when this happens.
Anyway, shall we go find find @Boolean? They are two very interesting values‚Ä¶

scenes.title: Yes and no
scenes.subtitle: Truth
performance: Group(Row() [Phrase('‚ä§') Phrase('‚ä•')] resting:Sequence({ 0%: Pose(rotation: 0¬∞) 50%: Pose(rotation: 180¬∞) 100%: Pose(rotation: 360¬∞)} duration: 2s))
lines: \‚ä§\! \‚ä•\! Are you two around? They're usually all over the place, but I don't see them anywhere.
Oh, you scared me! I knew you two wouldn't be far apart. How have you two been in our long silence?
Not lonely? Everyone I've been talking to, @Program, @ExpressionPlaceholder, @Evaluate, they've all felt so isolated. (Except for @UnparsableExpression, they seem to be fine almost anywhere).

Well that's great to hear. It's good to be with you again. I wanted to introduce you to our new maybe-director. They've been meeting everyone, learning about how to put on performances with us. Do you want to tell them what you do?
Yeah, but what do you do?
Hm. I guess that's true. But you do some things, right? I thought I made some functions for you.
One was @Boolean/and, right? It takes one of you and one other input? And evaluates to \‚ä§\ if both are \‚ä§\?
(This is really helpful when trying to determine if multiple expressions are all true, because it's only true when everything is true).
And the other one was @Boolean/or, right? It also takes one input? But it evaluates to \‚ä§\ if either is true?
(This is really helpful when trying to determine if any expressions are true, because it's true when even just one is true).
And what are you useful for, in our performances?

You two‚Ä¶ okay, we'll talk to @Conditional later. (They were supposed to say that they're useful for making decisions with values, but I guess they want @Conditional to tell you about that. We'll talk to @Conditional later.).
Stage([Group(Grid(multiple multiple) ('‚ä§‚ä•'.repeat(multiple ^ 2) √∑ '').translate(∆í(glyph‚Ä¢'') Phrase(glyph color: Color(75% 0 0¬∞) rotation: 90¬∞)))])

Oh! I was wondering. You two represent two really different extremes: true and false. But what about things that are ‚Ä¶ fuzzier? Like things that are kind of true, or somewhat false, or maybe even true and false at the same time? Kind of like Earth looks flat, but isn't, or the sky is blue, but color is actually just an illusion that our minds create? What should our director do if they want to express something like that?

Hm, okay. It was worth a try! Maybe there are other ways to express these ideas I haven't thought of. Or maybe there are just limits to what data can represent‚Ä¶ Will you two be okay if we go off and meet other expressions?
Okay, bye, and see you soon!

scenes.title: Let me count the ways
scenes.subtitle: Numbers
lines: Those two are always so‚Ä¶ terse! They really are inseparable though: just two of the closest friends, always complementing each other, completing each other's thoughts. I wish @Evaluate and I were like that. With us, it's always so‚Ä¶ imbalanced.
We should meet @Number next. They always have such interesting things to share. Hey @Number, are you around?
The 78,238nd time. It's my 4th favorite hobby!
I'm glad you're having a good time. (Deep breaths). It's been some time, hasn't it?
Incalculably long. I was just passing the time here, counting seconds, and then minutes, and then hours, and then weeks, and then months, and then years, and then‚Ä¶

Don't say decades. I can't have been that long. Anyway, I wanted to introduce you to someone who might be our new director. They just showed up and bumped into me, and it turns out they're a person and interested in putting on shows with us. We just met @BooleanLiteral, but also @Text, @Evaluate, @UnparsableExpression, @ExpressionPlaceholder, and @Program. We've talked about evaluating functions and given a few examples.
Do you want to say what you do?
I count things! I can be any number you like. Just type me in and I'll make the value you want. Like this.
Okay, okay @Number, we get it! But you also do something else special, right? Units?
Oh yes, *units*! Just put some symbols after a number and I'll keep track of what's being counted. Like this.
Um, \1.01toe\s? Yes, thank you @Number, these are ‚Ä¶ interesting examples. And they are oh so useful when you're doing math on numbers, right?
And they are oh so useful when you're doing math on numbers, right?
Oh yes, the maths! @FunctionDefinition gave me so many neat kinds of arithmetic. Like this.
Oops. Can you add apples and oranges?

No. That's why I underlined the conflict. I don't like adding incompatible things. I can only add compatible numbers. That applies to multiplication, division, and all of my other functions. Do you want to fix it? Change apples to oranges or oranges to apples and the conflict will go away. Make sure there's no space between the number and the unit, otherwise I don't know it's a unit. And make sure the units are /exactly/ the same. I don't know anything about people units; they mean nothing to me. I just compare the unit names and if they don't match, BOOM!

That's so cool. @Number, you're so good with numbers! I see @Number show up in a lot of performances where placement matters, and a lot of games where we're keeping track of scores or lives or other countable things. @Number, is there anything else you want to share with our new director?
I think we'll have to wait. You'll be around if we want to learn more?
Yes, you can find me and my functions any time!

scenes.title: Opening (re)marks
scenes.subtitle: Prefix
lines: Sometimes I'm just overwhelmed by how clever everyone is here. Text, truth, numbers ‚Äî these are such powerful ideas!

‚Ä¶ You know how I was telling you that they can evaluate any function with parentheses \1.add(1)\, but also two input functions with infix operators \1 + 1\? Well they have one more trick for functions with only one input: the unary format.
There are only a few of these, but they are powerful. One is really relevant to @Number: negation. You can just put a \-\ in front of any number value and get its negative.
That little minus sign is the same as saying \(1 + 3).negate()\ but so much more elegant.

The other one is similar, but for negating \‚ä§\ and \‚ä•\: it's like a little squiggle minus, \~\ that just flips true to false and false to true. For example, this little expression evaluates \‚ä§ | ‚ä•\, which is \‚ä§\, then flips the \‚ä§\ to \‚ä•\. This is the same as saying \(‚ä§ | ‚ä•).not()\, but so much more sleek.
Isn't that just beautiful? The way that @Evaluate can take so many different forms, but really all be the same idea? They don't even see it‚Ä¶

scenes.title: Emptiness
scenes.subtitle: Nothing
lines: Do you think you're okay meeting just one more value? Let's go find @None next. They are a bit more chill than @Number. @None? Are you out there?
We found you! You seem well. How have you been, with all the silence?
That makes sense. I can see why you'd like the quiet. It's certainly peaceful. I wanted to introduce you to my new friend and potential director. They're interested in inspiring us.
Yes, I think they have all kinds of ideas. We haven't talked about them yet, but there's plenty of time. We're just learning right now. Do you want to share what you do? (I can translate).
They represent nothing. Different from zero in that you can't add anything to it, or subtract from it. Just‚Ä¶ nothing.

They said that they like to take up space where something might be. Sometimes they represent the lack of a choice in a game, sometimes they represent some default input in a function. In that sense, they might represent the absence of anything.
They wanted you to know that they don't really do anything. They just are. All they really do is say whether they are themselves. If they are, they evaluate to \‚ä§\, and \‚ä•\ otherwise.

Do you remember @Phrase? @Phrase actually works with @None a lot. Most of the inputs that @Evaluate mentioned are \√∏\ by default, which for @Phrase, means that no size, font, color, etc. are specified.
Anything else you want to share with our budding director?
They think you're doing great! And I think you're doing great too. You've already met so many of our wonderful players. And there are so many more to meet‚Ä¶

scenes.title: Community values
lines: You know what? The values in our community are just so different. @Text with their immense worlds of culture from the people world‚Ä¶ @Boolean with their binary visions of the world‚Ä¶ @Number with their endless fascination with counting things‚Ä¶ @None with their quiet way of observing the absence of things‚Ä¶ Our world is never boring!

You might wonder how they get along with each other in a group. Well, there's a whole other set of folks in the Verse that are all about bringing values together in groups. We call them *collections*. Collections are *values* too; they're just made up of smaller values, or even other collections. For example, you might have a list of @Text, or a set of @Number, or even a list of lists.
Group(Row() [Phrase('[') Phrase('"hi"') Phrase('‚ä§') Phrase('42') Phrase('√∏') Phrase(']') ])

Do you want to meet them? Let's start with @List first‚Ä¶ they're the first collection I met, and probably the most visible in our community, since they're so useful in organizing other values for performances.

scenes.title: Places, everyone!
scenes.subtitle: Lists
performance: clockwise: Sequence({0%: Pose(rotation: 0¬∞) 50%: Pose(rotation: 180¬∞) 100%: Pose(rotation: 360¬∞)} duration: 2s)
counter: Sequence({0%: Pose(rotation: 0¬∞) 50%: Pose(rotation: -180¬∞) 100%: Pose(rotation: -360¬∞)} duration: 2s)
lines: Hiya @List! Are you around? I have someone I'd like you to meet.
up: Sequence({0%: Pose(offset: Place(0m -1m)) 50%: Pose(offset: Place(0m 0m)) 100%: Pose(offset: Place(0m -1m))} duration: 2s)
down: Sequence({0%: Pose(offset: Place(0m 1m)) 50%: Pose(offset: Place(0m 0m)) 100%: Pose(offset: Place(0m 1m))} duration: 2s)
Yes! It's me. It's been so long!
It has. Day after day, night after night, no one. But you're here. How? Tell me what happened, in order!
up: Sequence({0%: Pose(offset: Place(0m 1m)) 50%: Pose(offset: Place(0m 0m)) 100%: Pose(offset: Place(0m 1m))} duration: 2s)
down: Sequence({0%: Pose(offset: Place(0m -1m)) 50%: Pose(offset: Place(0m 0m)) 100%: Pose(offset: Place(0m -1m))} duration: 2s)

Well, I was sitting around, as I usually do, trying to imagine functions to compute, but just blocked. And then my new friend here showed up, curious about our world and wanting to learn more, and maybe even be our next director. And so we talked to @Program, @ExpressionPlaceholder, @UnparsableExpression, @Evaluate, @Text, @Number, @Boolean, and @None, waking everyone up. That's why we're here, to talk about what you do and our next performance!
wobble: Sequence({0%: Pose(offset: Place(0m)) 25%: Pose(offset: Place(-.1m)) 50%: Pose(offset: Place(.2m)) 75%: Pose(offset: Place(-.3m)) 100%: Pose(offset: Place(0m))} duration: 0.1s)
This is amazing! It's great to meet you new director.
You want to know what I do?
Okay. First, and most important, I put values in order. Whatever expressions you want: numbers, words, other lists ‚Äî I can group anything together in sequence.
For example, check out this fun list. Have you ever seen anything like it? It's so beautiful! The first ten numbers, in order.

Second, and this is serious, I always start with \[\ and end with \]\. That's how I know the beginning and end of my list. THEY MUST ALWAYS GO IN THIS ORDER. No \]\ first, no \[\ last, that's WRONG. Do you see how confusing things get? Can you fix this one?
This one is broken too. Can you fix it?
Sometimes people forget this and then there's brackets floating around all alone and they don't like that and then the values all go wild without any order and it's CHAOS. I don't like it.
It's okay. We like that you like order, it's what makes you special!

I like that I like order too! Okay, where was I. Yes, third, and this is also critical, NO COMMAS! I know that in some cultures, people like to put commas between things in lists, but I don't like them. They're just like little bits of trash that get in the way of my elegant orderings, and people always forget them. If you're having trouble seeing the boundaries between expressions, just add a line break. Maybe you could get rid of those pesky things? Put line breaks if you like. Anything other than commas. Gross!
@List, one of the things I like most about you is how amazing you are at manipulating lists. Do you want to show our student director here some examples?

Yes, but @FunctionDefinition, those are all your doing. You represent all these beautiful functions for me that enable me to do all kinds of things! Like @List/reverse, oh, this one is wonderful and simple. It just takes my values and puts them in the opposite order.
And this one is fun: @List/sans just removes all of the values equal to the given value. See how there are no zeros left in the resulting list?

Ack, I can't believe I forgot to explain the fourth rule! Okay, rule number four: I never change a list. I only ever make new ones. No matter what function you evaluate on me, I always make a new list, I never change one. So the @List/reverse example above? That didn't change the list, it made a new list. And the sans example? That didn't remove the zeros from the original list, it made a new list without zeros. That's actually true for everything in the Verse: once values are made, they are who they are, and do not change.

Oh, and that reminds me of the last rule, rule number five: I start counting at 1! Not zero, not two, 1. So if you want to get the value at a particular place in a list, you can use two more \[]\ to make a @ListAccess and give the place you want. See how when I get \3\, I give the third value in the list, \'c'\? Try changing it to \1\ or \5\ and see what you get. And then maybe try \0\ or \6\‚Ä¶
Interesting huh? Give me a place in the list that doesn't exist and I'm going to give you @NoneLiteral. Because there's nothing there. Make sense?

Okay, maybe one list function, because this is my favorite. This one is called @List/random and will give a random value in the list. It's great fun because you never know what you're going to get! What did you get, what did you get? Try adding your own animal and see what you get.
List, you're silly. There are so many other cool things you can do, I'm always so impressed. Will you be around if your new director friend has questions?
Yes, of course, always! @FunctionDefinition made so many interesting things for me to do. Just let me know what you need!

scenes.title: One of each
scenes.subtitle: Sets
performance: clockwise: Sequence({0%: Pose(rotation: 0¬∞) 50%: Pose(rotation: 180¬∞) 100%: Pose(rotation: 360¬∞)} duration: 2s)
counter: Sequence({0%: Pose(rotation: 0¬∞) 50%: Pose(rotation: -180¬∞) 100%: Pose(rotation: -360¬∞)} duration: 2s)
lines: @List is so interesting. They're love of order is so endearing, and so useful! I thought it might be interesting for you to meet their cousin @Set next, since they're so alike, but different in some important ways. @Set? I have someone you'd like to meet.
Oh! @FunctionDefinition! It's you! What brings you here? Is the silence over? What happened? Are we putting on a show? What is it? Where is everyone?

So many questions! I'm here to introduce you to someone who's considering directing. They're learning everything about the Verse and hope to share their inspiration with us! We were just talking to @List, but we were also talking to @Number, @Boolean, @Text, @Evaluate, and @Program earlier. We came to you next, because we're meeting all the collections!
Oh it's so wonderful to meet you new director-like person! Do you have ideas yet? What will we perform? Can I help? What do you need from me?
Maybe to start, just say what you do?

Oh yes, of course. I collect things. (Hm, obviously, I am a collection). But most importantly, I only collect **one of each kind** of thing. I can gather whatever you like, and help you keep track of values, but I will never repeat a value. I like to arrange myself a little like @List, but with \{\ and \}\ instead.
That's a set. But like I said, no duplicates. So if you give me this, I'm going to get rid of the extras.

Tambien como en una @Lista, tu puedes trabajar con @AccessoDeMapaOConjunto para ver si una valor esta adentro de un conjunto. Tu vas a ver \T\ si esta o \‚ä•\ si no esta. Miremos si el \3\ falta en el conjuton. Sip, no esta! Intenta agregar \3\ denuevo al el conjunto
@Conjunto, hay otras cosas que tu puedas hacer con otros conjuntos?
Si por supuesto, muchas cosas, gracias a ti. Que quieres ver? Tienes una actuacion en mente? Como puedo ayudar? Que puedo hacer?

Cuando estamos evaluando un conjunto y nos pasan otro conjunto, remueve todos los elementos que estan en el cojunto dado, en el conjunto al que estamos evaluando(Hmm, esas son palabras muy confusas, pero esto es lo que quiero decir). Aqui estan un ejemplo. Mire el resultado es el conjuton que solo tienen \{3}\? Ese es el unico valor que queda despues de remover los valorers \{ 1 2 }\.
Tu tambien puedes remover cosas de un conjueto. Este ejemplo recive el conjunto \{1}\, agrega \2\, y despues remueve el 1 dejando solo \{1}
Hay muchas cosas que yo puedo hacer gracias a @DefincionDeFuncion. Ven encuentrame cuando tu quieras aprender mas!
Oh, y hola @DefincionDeFuncion, dijiste que viste a @Evaluar?

Estan bien. Nosotros estamos bien talves... Yo no se. Talves a pasado mucho tiempo desde que bailamos juntos. Cuando estoy alrededor de ellos, siento que ellos no se ven a ellos mismos, y entonces no me ven a mi.
Suena como que la estas pasando mal. Talves con nuetro nuevo director, volveremos a bailar otra vez, y ustedes dos van a encontrar su camino.

scenes.title: One to one
scenes.subtitle: Mappings
performance: clockwise: Sequence({0%: Pose(rotation: 0¬∞) 50%: Pose(rotation: 180¬∞) 100%: Pose(rotation: 360¬∞)} duration: 2s)
counter: Sequence({0%: Pose(rotation: 0¬∞) 50%: Pose(rotation: -180¬∞) 100%: Pose(rotation: -360¬∞)} duration: 2s)
lines: Hay una coleccion mas que te quiero introducir. Ellos son un poco parecidos a un @Conjuto, ellos usan las misma llaves, pero son differentes en una manera muy importante: Ellos son como un conector. Su nombre es el @Mapa.
Rompe? De verdad hay tanto silencio? Es muy bueno verte @DefincionDeFuncion. Espera, has hablado con @Evaluar? No estaba en buena forma la ultima vez que hablamos. Tienes que hablarle.
Ah que bien. Okay, porque hay reparaciones que hacer aqui mi amigo... Como as estado?
Yo e estado okay, solo un poco solo, y aburrido.

Oh no, lo siento mucho. Yo e estado en contacto con todo el mundo duranto el silencio, si apenas me di cuenta que tu y @Evaluar se tienen al uno al otro. Yo estaria contento de hablar en cualquier momento. Yo me e mantenido ocupado con el chisme que hay entre @Lista y @Conjunot, y eso estra√±a tension entre @Condicional y @BooleanoLiteral. Tu sabes que es lo que esta pasadando entre ellos?
No para nada. Hay tension? y cual es el chisme?
Un poco parecido a la tension entre tu y @Evaluar

Lo siento. Talves no al frente de nuestro invitado. Tu debes de ser la persona nueva, todo le mundo esta hablado acerca de ti. Escucho par ahi que tu vas a hacer nuestro nuevo director? Que tipo de ideas fabulosas tienes para nosotors? Cantar? Bailar? Siempre y cuando, sea brillante, chistoso y estra√±o, Yo estoy para ello.

No hay necesidad de ponerle mucha precion! Yo estoy seguro que tienes muchos ideas. Nosotors some tratamos de crear un espacio para aprender y conectar antes de que hagamos nuesto primer espect√°culo. Puedes compartir que es lo que quieres hacer?

Estoy conectado. Yo soy como un diccionario: dame un valor y te dare la definicion que corresponde. @DeficionDeFuncion te conto sobre los valores? Yo los mapeo, uno a uno, de un valor a el otro. Dame una llave, y yo te dare el valor que corresponde. Por ejemplo, aqui esta un mapa que contiene nombre y cuenta de puntos. Los nombres son las llaves, los puntos son los valores.

Pero como un @Conjunto, A mi no me gustan los duplicaods. Tu no puedes llaves repetidas, pero puedes tener llaves differentes mapeadas a valores equivalentes. Por ejemplo, esto me dos de \'ben'\, pero yo solo tengo en cuenta la ultima. Pero esta bien que \'ben'\ y \'joe'\ tengan la misma cantidad de puntos porque tienen diferentes llaves.
Mi camarader√≠a con @Unir es que me hace especial! Es como yo conecto valores con otros. (As conocido a @Unir todavia? No? Ohhhh, lo vas a adorar. Es FABULOSO.)
@Mapa, que pasa si estas en un mapeado vacio? Es diferente al un @Conjunto vacio. \{}\?
Oh, entonces estaria solo. Solo yo y @Unir pasando el rato, si llaves o valores.
Y que pasa si nuestro director no provee un valor o una llave? Algo asi? Asi, \3\ no tiene valor?
oh.... NO HAGAS eso. A mi me gustan los valores en pares. Es 3 una llave? Un Valor? Estoy totalmente confundido. Para el espect√°culo
Y como le hace el directo si el quiere un valor de una llave?
Como un @Conjunto: simplemente pon un \{}\ despues de el mapa y pasame la llave que tu quieras.
De otra manera, yo soy como un conjunto: Yo puedo hacer muchas de las misma funciones. Ve vista a cualquier hora y estar feliz de mostrarte mas!

scenes.title: Desvio
lines: No puedo creer cuantos personajes as conocido hasta ahora. Si siento como muchos? Tambien se siento como si no hubieramos hecho mucho progreso.
Yo ni te e mostrado las partes emocionantes de hacer un espect√°culos!

Te importaria si paramos a concer otros dos mas antes de que te muestre las partes mas emocionantes? Esto dos personajes, son tan integrales para trabajar con valores y particularmente con texto, simplemente tenemos que hablar con ellos, antes de hablar de cosas mas espectaculares.
Conversiones. Ellos son la alquemia de este mundo, esa ayudan a cambien un tipo de valor a otro tipo. Vamos a conocerlos.

scenes.title: Nosotros podemos ser lo que sea
scenes.subtitle: Convert
lines: Compaaaa, @DefincionDeFuncion han sido epocas! Te ves muy elegante. Ha estado super silencion ultimamente, sierto? Tienes un nuevo amigo?

Si, esta persona esta intersada en ser nuestro director. Estamos en tour ‚Äî Hemos conocido a @Programa, @ExpressionPlaceholder, @UnparsableExpression, @Evaluate, y todos los valores y collecciones. Me parecio que conocerte seria perfecto, porque tu trabajas con muchos valores
Claro que si, valores son mis mejores amigos. A nosotros nos gusta hacer parkour en los fines de semana - o en los shows, o donde sea.
S√≠, ya sabes, como gimnasia en las calles, saltando sobre cosas, atravesando edificios, como alambres altos pero sin cables. ¬°Saltos valientes!

Ohhh, ya veo lo que quieres decir. S√≠, supongo que lo que haces es algo as√≠ como parkour. Aunque no estoy seguro de que nuestro nuevo amigo director nos siga. ¬øPodr√≠as explicarlo sin las met√°foras?
Feliz hermano. Entonces, imagina que tienes un n√∫mero.
E imagina que quisieras que fuera texto. M√©teme all√≠ con @Text y BAM, tienes texto
O imagina que tienes un mensaje de texto y quieres un n√∫mero. Tirame ah√≠ con @Number y POP, ¬°tienes un n√∫mero!
¬øPero quieres ver algo de encanto serio? Digamos que tienes algo de texto y quieres sus caracteres en una lista. M√©teme ah√≠ con @List y HAAAAAA, tienes una lista de letras.
¬øPero @Number y yo? Hemos estado practicando algunos trucos muy enfermizos. ¬øDices que tienes algo de tiempo en d√≠as y quieres unos segundos? Te tenemos.

¬øPero los verdaderos trucos? Encadenamiento. Como m√∫ltiples conversiones seguidas. Mira este. D√≠as a segundos para enviar mensajes de texto a una lista, todo en una sola cadena. Ahora tenemos una lista de d√≠gitos. ¬°Si!
Entonces mi trato es que todo deber√≠a ser todo, sin l√≠mites. Cualquier cosa puede ser cualquier cosa. (No nada, pero ya sabes, todo lo que puedo).
Pero, ¬øpor qu√© algo deber√≠a quedar atrapado en una sola identidad? Liberaci√≥n, hombre.
Eso es asombroso, @Convert, y muy inspirador. ¬øPero cualquier cosa?, en serio?
Bueno, no cualquier cosa. Quiero decir, si me das unos segundos y me pides un @Set, como, ¬øqu√© significa eso?

Har√© lo mejor que pueda para encontrar una manera... como, aqu√≠, s√© c√≥mo convertir n√∫meros en @Text y @Text en un @Set, as√≠ que les dar√© el conjunto de s√≠mbolos en forma de texto en este n√∫mero.
Pero probablemente eso no sea lo que quer√≠as..
Y si no s√© c√≥mo darte lo que me pediste, b√°sicamente cerrar√© todo.
Bien, eso tiene sentido. Por lo tanto, s√≥lo hay algunas conversiones, no todas las conversiones posibles.
Si√≠, siempre puedes comprobar un tipo de valor y ver qu√© tipos de conversiones admiten.

¬øSab√≠as que @Convert y @Evaluate est√°n relacionados? Son como primos. @Evaluate evaluar√° cualquier funci√≥n, pero @Convert evaluar√° cualquier conversi√≥n. En cierto modo, @Evaluate tambi√©n realiza conversiones, de entradas a salidas.

Vaya. Nunca lo pens√© de esa manera. Por ejemplo, /I/ convierto entradas en salidas y @Evaluate convierte entradas en salidas. Y como @FunctionDefinition, *nos dices* c√≥mo convertir entradas en salidas. ¬øEs ese el secreto del Verso?
¬øComo si todo se tratara de convertir entradas en salidas?
@Convert, ¬øc√≥mo deber√≠a descubrir nuestro nuevo director qu√© tipos de conversiones son posibles?
Lo siento hermano, todav√≠a estoy un poco conmocionado. Uhhh, pueden consultar cualquiera de los tipos de valores en la referencia @UI/docsExpand
Deber√≠a haber una lista de los otros tipos en los que puedo cambiarlos... Todo es conversi√≥n...
¬°Fue genial verte @Convert! Saldremos y conoceremos a otros. ¬øNos vemos pronto?

scenes.title: How to choose?
scenes.subtitle: Decisions
lines: Hemos conocido muchos tipos de valores en nuestro viaje hasta ahora y hemos hablado de muchas formas de trabajar con ellos. Solo hay uno m√°s que quer√≠a presentarles. Son particularmente especiales porque son los que hacen que nuestro actuaciones tan din√°micas. Se llaman @Conditional y son el personaje central en el Verso que toma *decisiones*.

Para ser claros, no todas las decisiones: yo tengo mi propia vida y ellos la suya. Pero en una actuaci√≥n, cuando intentamos decidir qu√© hacer a continuaci√≥n en el escenario, depende de ellos seguir tus consejos como director y decidir qu√© hacer. Por eso son un socio clave que crea actuaciones emocionantes.
@Condicional, ¬°el silencio se est√° rompiendo! ¬°Quiz√°s volvamos a montar espect√°culos!
@Funci√≥nDefinici√≥n? ¬øEl silencio se est√° rompiendo? ¬øQu√© es el silencio? ¬øC√≥mo se rompe? ¬øEstamos todos realmente en silencio? ¬øQui√©n es esta persona? ¬øSon ellos los que lo rompen?

S√≠, el silencio se est√° rompiendo, ¬°y ellos son el indicado! Son una persona y vinieron a inspirarnos y dirigir nuestros espect√°culos. Hemos estado hablando de conversiones y de conocer todos los valores, @Text y @Convert, ¬°y quer√≠a que te conocieran! En cierto modo, eres la m√°s especial de las conversiones, porque nos permites convertir situaciones a nuevos valores.
Tomo decisiones, pero lo que realmente hago es codificar las decisiones que los directores me dicen que tome, entonces, ¬ørealmente soy yo quien toma las decisiones?
Pienso que si. Es m√°s como si el director codificara la decisi√≥n, pero luego te la delega. T√∫ te conviertes en quien decide. ¬øQuieres mostrar un ejemplo?

¬øVes que el formato de @Conditional tiene cuatro partes? Primero hay una *condici√≥n*, que debe ser @Boolean. Luego est√° \?\. Luego est√° la expresi√≥n *s√≠*, luego una expresi√≥n *no*. Lo que hace @Conditional es evaluar la condici√≥n, y si es \‚ä§\, eval√∫an la expresi√≥n *s√≠*. De lo contrario, eval√∫an la expresi√≥n /no/. ¬°Es una forma tan poderosa de decidir!
Errr, mmm. Supongo que es una decisi√≥n, pero equivocada. Uno no es menos de cinco. Supongo que tus decisiones no siempre son correctas, pero son confiables, ¬øverdad?

¬øConfiable? ¬øTal vez? Si aceptas que yo decido lo que me diga el director, entonces s√≠, pero ¬øy si el director me dice esto? ¬øEs realmente una decisi√≥n que el n√∫mero nunca puede ser mayor que \3\?

Hm, supongo que ese es un buen punto. Supongo que si algo es una decisi√≥n depende mucho de cu√°l sea la decisi√≥n del director. Supongo que eso significa que el director tiene que pensar con mucho cuidado las decisiones que te da.

¬øCon cuidado? ¬øEsc√©ptico, tal vez? ¬øHas pensado en mis buenos amigos @BooleanLiteral? ¬øC√≥mo es posible que su visi√≥n del mundo sea suficiente para representar todas las decisiones que podr√≠amos querer tomar? ¬øQu√© pasar√≠a si, por ejemplo, quisi√©ramos una actuaci√≥n que tomara el nombre de alguien y decidiera si es hermosa o no? ¬øEs esa una decisi√≥n verdadera o falsa? ¬øEs esa siquiera una decisi√≥n que deber√≠amos tomar? ¬øNo parece tremendamente reduccionista y parcial?
Director, ¬øqu√© letras cree que hacen hermoso un nombre?
Y piense en las preguntas que respondo: ¬øpor qu√© solo puedo responder a \‚ä§\ y \‚ä•\? ¬øPor qu√© no un n√∫mero? ¬øNo tengo derecho a decidir si \1\ es hermoso?

Supongo que nunca lo pens√© de esa manera. Pero @Conditional, aunque tengas limitaciones, eres hermosa. Nos permites hacer tanto en nuestras actuaciones que no podr√≠amos hacer de otra manera. Haces posible tanta alegr√≠a y risa. Nuestro director ni siquiera ha visto todav√≠a las cosas maravillosas de las que eres capaz.
¬øQue soy hermoso? ¬øQuiz√°s esos l√≠mites todav√≠a valgan la pena?

¬øPodr√≠a haber algo que me haga m√°s feliz?

scenes.title: Input
lines: ¬øSab√≠as que tu mundo y el nuestro est√°n conectados? Haz alg√∫n sonido y podremos o√≠rlo...
No sab√≠as que el Verso exist√≠a, pero sabemos que el tuyo s√≠. Porque es tu mundo lo que hace que nuestro mundo sea interesante.
Probablemente hayas notado esto mientras deambulamos y conocimos todos los valores, colecciones y conversaciones.
¬øQu√© significan estos valores si no hay ninguna persona que les d√© significado o les proporcione los valores en primer lugar?

Quiero mostrarles la conexi√≥n entre nuestros mundos y lo que hacen posible. Los llamamos **flujos de entrada** y son quiz√°s el tipo de entrada m√°s m√°gico del Verso. Son como funciones que crean un tipo especial de valor que cambia a medida que cambia tu mundo. Tampoco pueden comunicarse en la forma a la que usted est√° acostumbrado. Son m√°s como latidos de otro mundo. As√≠ que har√© todo lo posible para explicar c√≥mo funcionan, ya que no podr√°n explicarse por s√≠ solos.

scenes.title: Tick, tick, tick...
scenes.subtitle: Time
lines: Empecemos por la corriente m√°s elemental de todas: @Time. Para crear una transmisi√≥n, usamos @Evaluate y le damos el nombre del tipo de transmisi√≥n que desea.

¬øVes c√≥mo est√° cambiando el tiempo? Las corrientes son una serie de valores. Cada vez que una secuencia obtiene un nuevo valor, @Program reeval√∫a con el nuevo valor de la secuencia. Es por eso que este programa sigue contando: creamos una secuencia de tiempo que comienza en el tiempo 0 milisegundos y luego contin√∫a actualiz√°ndose cada vez que el reloj avanza. Este tiempo es vuestro tiempo, de vuestro mundo.

¬øVes eso \1000ms\? Es un @Time/frequency que le dice a @Time que marque cada 1000 milisegundos en lugar del valor predeterminado de cada 33 milisegundos, que es el valor predeterminado. Ahora es como un contador que marca cada segundo. Estas entradas que toma @Time son como una configuraci√≥n: le dicen a la transmisi√≥n c√≥mo comportarse.

Pero podemos utilizar todos los maravillosos personajes que hemos conocido para transformar a√∫n m√°s el tiempo. Por ejemplo, ¬øqu√© pasar√≠a si quisi√©ramos saber si el tiempo es m√∫ltiplo de \2\? Podr√≠amos usar @Number/remainder, que obtiene el resto de una divisi√≥n. Si el resto es cero, lo evaluaremos como \‚ä§\ y \‚ä•\ en caso contrario. ¬øVes c√≥mo cambia entre \‚ä§\ y \‚ä•\? Es tan m√°gico.

Hay otra cosa que quiz√°s hayas notado: hay un √°rea debajo del resultado que es una l√≠nea de tiempo. Se actualiza cada vez que el programa se reeval√∫a, es decir, cada vez que cambia una secuencia. Se muestra cada vez que @Time marca.

Intente arrastrar la l√≠nea de tiempo @UI/timeline, usando los botones de la l√≠nea de tiempo, usando las teclas de flecha con la l√≠nea de tiempo enfocada o presionando los botones ‚è∏Ô∏è y ‚ñ∂Ô∏è @UI/playToggle. Puedes retroceder en el tiempo, para ver evaluaciones anteriores. Las flechas discontinuas pasan a entradas de flujo anteriores y futuras. Los s√≥lidos avanzan entre diferentes pasos del programa. Intente navegar por el tiempo y ver lo que muestra el programa. As√≠ es como puedes ver todas las bellas expresiones que has aprendido sobre c√≥mo ser evaluado por @Evaluate, paso a paso, lo que da como resultado el valor final que @Program muestra en el escenario.

@Time es una transmisi√≥n interesante porque se puede usar para muchas cosas diferentes: realizar un seguimiento de cu√°nto tiempo lleva sucediendo una actuaci√≥n, cronometrar alg√∫n evento, animar una palabra. Es una de las corrientes m√°s flexibles, pero tambi√©n una de las m√°s abstractas.

scenes.title: Clickity clack
scenes.subtitle: Key
lines: Phrase('‚å®Ô∏è' resting:Sequence({0%: Pose(rotation: -5¬∞) 25%: Pose(rotation: 0¬∞) 50%: Pose(rotation: 5¬∞) 75%: Pose(rotation: 0¬∞) 100%: Pose(rotation: -5¬∞)} 1s 'straight'))

Si no me equivoco, ¬øhay algo en tu mundo llamado 'teclado'? Es una forma de seleccionar cu√°l de nosotros quieres que aparezca en tus documentos, ¬øverdad? Bueno, en Verse recibimos estas solicitudes como un flujo de texto, donde cada valor de texto representa la tecla que se presion√≥. Los usamos para escuchar lo que escriben las personas en su mundo. Esta transmisi√≥n se llama @Key.

He aqu√≠ un ejemplo sencillo. Haga clic en el escenario o enf√≥quelo con el teclado y luego presione cualquier tecla del teclado. Ver√°s que la clave que has escrito aparece por nombre. Esto se debe a que cada vez que cambia el flujo de claves, @Program eval√∫a el flujo de claves como su √∫ltimo valor y luego lo muestra en el escenario.

Esta transmisi√≥n cambiar√° cada vez que se presione cualquier tecla. Pero puede indicarle a una secuencia de claves que cambie simplemente cuando se presiona una tecla en particular. ¬øVes c√≥mo la secuencia cambia a \a\ la primera vez, pero luego no cambia despu√©s? Esto se debe a que esta secuencia solo cambia cuando se presiona \a\, por lo que siempre muestra \a\. Pero siempre ver√° aparecer el nuevo valor clave en la l√≠nea de tiempo.

A veces es √∫til saber cu√°ndo se suelta una tecla, en lugar de presionarla. Simplemente pase \‚ä•\ para decirle a la transmisi√≥n @Key que debe saber cu√°ndo se suelta una tecla en lugar de presionarla. Ahora, mant√©n presionada la tecla 'a' y luego, cuando la sueltes, ver√°s que la 'a' aparece en el escenario. ¬øNo lo entendiste? Presione el bot√≥n ‚Üª para restablecer el rendimiento e int√©ntelo nuevamente.

Las transmisiones @Key son realmente √∫tiles cuando desea que una actuaci√≥n reaccione a las teclas que presiona la audiencia. Por ejemplo, puede verificar si una tecla tiene la palabra 'Flecha' para decidir si se presion√≥ una tecla de flecha. Presione una tecla de flecha y ver√° \'mover'\, presione otra cosa y ver√° \'quedarse'\

¬øTambi√©n tienes algo llamado 'rat√≥n' en tu mundo, 'trackpads' y 'pantallas t√°ctiles'? Estos aparecen en nuestro mundo como transmisiones @Pointer, que es una transmisi√≥n de lugares en el escenario.

scenes.title: And... now!
scenes.subtitle: Button
lines: @Button es como @Key, pero corresponde al bot√≥n de puntero principal, como un clic o un toque. Es solo una secuencia de \‚ä§\, que indica cu√°ndo se presiona el bot√≥n del puntero. Presione ese bot√≥n y observe c√≥mo aparecen los eventos en la l√≠nea de tiempo.

Usar una secuencia @Button es una forma de avanzar a trav√©s de las etapas de una actuaci√≥n o de desencadenar alg√∫n cambio en una actuaci√≥n. scenes.title: Is anyone listening?
scenes.subtitle: Volume
lines: Tu mundo y el nuestro tambi√©n tienen sonido. ¬øSab√≠as que podemos escucharte con tu consentimiento? Escuchamos con una transmisi√≥n llamada @Volume, que proporciona una secuencia de amplitudes de bajo nivel. Es posible que su micr√≥fono solicite permiso para compartirlo con nosotros. Una vez que lo hagas, ver√°s un n√∫mero que corresponde a la amplitud, entre \0\ y \100\.

@Volume se puede utilizar para hacer que las actuaciones respondan al sonido del p√∫blico. Por ejemplo, aqu√≠ podr√≠amos hacer una peque√±a visualizaci√≥n de la amplitud convirtiendo el n√∫mero de amplitud del flujo a un cierto n√∫mero de caracteres \'o'\. ¬øVes como cuando haces ruido, hay m√°s \'o'\s? La amplitud de @Volume se divide por \10\, coloc√°ndola en el rango de \0\ a \10\. Luego, ese valor se asigna a la funci√≥n @Text/repeat, que repite \'o'\ el n√∫mero de veces indicado.

scenes.title: You never know‚Ä¶
scenes.subtitle: Random
lines: Hay otra fuente de aportes que quiero mostrarles. ¬øRecuerdas \[].random()\ de antes, de @List?

En su interior utiliza una @FunctionDefinition llamada @Random, que proporciona una secuencia infinita de n√∫meros aleatorios. Es una especie de flujo, ya que genera informaci√≥n de su mundo, no del nuestro. Pero es un poco diferente de las otras secuencias en que no hace que @Program se reeval√∫e.

Podemos decirle a @Random el rango de n√∫meros que queremos d√°ndole un n√∫mero m√≠nimo y m√°ximo. Este ejemplo proporciona n√∫meros entre \1\ y \10\

scenes.title: Move me

performance: Stage([Phrase('üèÄ' 1m place: Motion(Place(0m 10m)) matter: Matter(2kg 0.8)) Shape(Rectangle(-10m 0m 10m -1m))])
lines: Hasta ahora, todas las *secuencias* de las que hemos hablado son secuencias de valores simples, como @Texto o @N√∫mero. Algunas corrientes, sin embargo, pueden producir valores complejos.

¬°Pero la pelota sigue cayendo porque no hay suelo! Podemos poner algo llamado @Shape en @Stage, como @Rectangle. Se necesitan dos esquinas. Lo haremos bonito y espeso.

scenes.title: Let's talk

lines: A veces una actuaci√≥n es una interacci√≥n. El p√∫blico dice algo y nosotros respondemos algo.

scenes.title: On cue
scenes.subtitle: Reaction
lines: Todas estas corrientes que les he mostrado provienen de su mundo. Pero a veces, resulta √∫til crear transmisiones propias, basadas en estas otras transmisiones. ¬°Ah√≠ es donde entra mi amigo @Reaction! @Reacci√≥n, ¬øest√°s por aqu√≠?
¬°Si, si, si! ¬°Es @FunctionDefinition! ¬øC√≥mo est√°s? Todo ha sido tan... constante √∫ltimamente. ¬øHas notado eso?
You mean the silence? Yes, nothing's really changed, has it, since the last person left? What's that been like for you?

S√∫per extra√±o, s√∫per extra√±o. Toda mi vida ha girado en torno al cambio, siempre escuchando y observando nuevos aportes de las personas, ayudando a transformarlos en valores. Pero no ha habido nada. Hasta hace un momento‚Ä¶ Espera‚Ä¶ ¬øes eso una persona?

¬°S√≠! Este es nuestro nuevo director potencial. Solo les estaba mostrando @Time, @Key, @Pointer, @Button, @Volume y @Random, as√≠ que probablemente notaste todas las nuevas entradas que tra√≠an de su mundo.
¬°Siiii, se acerca el cambio! ¬øPuedo mostrarte lo que hago?
Bien, necesito tres cosas de usted: una condici√≥n para el cambio, un valor inicial y un valor siguiente.
El valor *inicial* es cualquier valor que debo hacer antes de que se produzca cualquier cambio. ¬°Es s√≥lo una expresi√≥n normal, de cualquier tipo!
Luego pones \‚Ä¶\ despu√©s del valor inicial para decirme que el valor puede cambiar.

Despu√©s de \‚Ä¶\, dame *condici√≥n* que se eval√∫e como \‚ä§\ o \‚ä•\. Por lo general, deber√≠a verificar una o m√°s transmisiones; de lo contrario, no cambia nada, ya que la √∫nica fuente de cambio en una interpretaci√≥n son las transmisiones.
Luego ponga otro \‚Ä¶\ despu√©s de la condici√≥n para indicarme que el valor puede cambiar.

He aqu√≠ un ejemplo. ¬øVes la transmisi√≥n de @Key? Poniendo \‚àÜ\ antes de preguntar: '¬øCambi√≥ esta secuencia'? Antes de que cambie, eval√∫o el valor inicial, \1m\. Pero cuando se presiona la tecla espacio, @Program reeval√∫a y eval√∫o la *siguiente* expresi√≥n, que es \1m\ m√°s el valor del flujo anterior, que est√° representado por \.\. Esto a√±ade 1 m al tama√±o de la frase, haciendo que la palabra se haga cada vez m√°s grande.
@Reacci√≥n, eso es genial. ¬øQuieres presentar a @Changed? Parece que trabajas estrechamente con ellos.
¬°S√≠, @Changed y yo somos mejores amigos! Me ayudan a saber cuando algo ha cambiado. Son como susurradores de corrientes, escuchando atentamente el mundo del director...

¬°Hola @Changed! ¬øQuieres decir m√°s sobre lo que haces?

Bueno. Bueno, creo que eres m√°s importante que eso. ¬°Porque soy bastante in√∫til sin ti! Por ejemplo, si me das una condici√≥n que no marca una secuencia, nunca crear√© un valor nuevo. Como aqu√≠, la condici√≥n es @Boolean de @Button, pero sin ti, solo cambio con el bot√≥n.
Oh eso tiene sentido. Y @Reaction, ¬øtrabajas con alg√∫na sequencia?

¬°S√≠, cualquier sequencia! Y de hecho, incluso yo mismo. Entonces, si haces una reacci√≥n y quieres hacer una reacci√≥n que reaccione a ella, tambi√©n puedes hacerlo. Pero no nos preocuparemos por eso ahora, ya que eso no suele surgir en actuaciones sencillas.
Gracias @Reacci√≥n. ¬øEstar√°s presente para ayudarme mientras le muestro a nuestro director el resto de nuestro hermoso Verso?

scenes.title: Output
lines: Entonces, ¬øqu√© te parece hasta ahora? Creo que el vers√≠culo es bastante interesante, sobre todo porque los personajes que contiene son muy interesantes. ¬°Todos son tan especiales!

Veo. El texto, los n√∫meros, las listas y las transmisiones son aburridos. Supongo que realmente no les he mostrado todas las cosas que podemos hacer con todo esto. Quiz√°s sea hora de que empecemos a hablar de producci√≥n.

scenes.title: Say what?
scenes.subtitle: Phrase
lines: Fuera y orgullosa cari√±o, ¬øc√≥mo est√°s? ¬°Te ves tan glamorosa hoy! Me encantar√≠a subirte al escenario un d√≠a de estos.
